facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 93 of 1966 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 93 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal arose from judgment and order dated November 27, 1964 of Rajasthan High Court in D.B. Writ Petition No. 803 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated November 27, 1964 of the Rajasthan High Court in D. B. Writ Petition No. 803 of 1964.

facts.text: Rajasthan Higher Judicial Service Rules, 1955 were promulgated on May 9, 1955 by the Rajpramukh under proviso to Article 309.

anchor.surface_text: On May 9, 1955, the Rajpramukh of the then  Part B  State of Rajasthan, in exercise of the powers conferred by the proviso to Art. 309 of the Constitution, promulgated the Rajasthan Higher Judicial Service Rules, 1955.

facts.text: High Court of Rajasthan published notice dated November 20, 1963 inviting applications for direct recruitment to four posts of Civil and Additional Sessions Judge.

anchor.surface_text: In pursuance of the said Rules, the High Court of Rajasthan published a notice dated November 20, 1963, inviting applications for direct recruitment to four posts of Civil and Additional Sessions Judge.

facts.text: Selection Committee selected four candidates after scrutiny and interviews for direct recruitment.

anchor.surface_text: A number of applications were received by the High Court and after scrutiny thereof and interviews granted to the applicants, the Selection Committee... selected four candidates.

facts.text: There were fourteen posts to be filled by promotion from Rajasthan Judicial Service; Selection Committee selected eligible candidates and prepared a list.

anchor.surface_text: Besides these four posts, there were fourteen posts to be filled up from amongst the members of the Rajasthan Judicial Service by promotion. The said Committee selected eligible candidates from amongst those members and prepared another list.

facts.text: High Court submitted the two lists prepared by the Selection Committee to the Governor for appointments.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court submitted the two lists prepared by the Committee to the Governor for appointments.

facts.text: Appellants, members of Rajasthan Judicial Service, filed writ petition in Rajasthan High Court challenging validity of selections, lists, and appointments as contravening Article 233.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants who are members of the Rajasthan Judicial Service filed a writ petition in the High Court of Rajasthan challenging the validity of the selection done, the lists prepared by the Selection Committee and the appointments made on the basis of those lists on the ground that they were done in contravention of Art. 233.

facts.text: Rajasthan High Court dismissed the writ petition holding the Rules valid and proceedings valid.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court dismissed the writ petition holding that the said Rules were valid, and, therefore, the proceedings of the said Committee, the lists prepared by it... were all valid.

facts.text: Supreme Court held Rajasthan Higher Judicial Service Rules, 1955 ultra vires Article 233; selections and appointments invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The Rules, therefore, are clearly inconsistent with the mandate provided for in Art. 233 and are, therefore, invalid. Consequently, the selections made by the Committee, the lists prepared by them and appointments made thereunder would be invalid.

facts.text: Appointments validated by Constitution (Twentieth Amendment) Act, 1966 introducing Article 233A.

anchor.surface_text: The next question is whether appointments made by the Governor from amongst those in the said lists are validated by the Constitution Twentieth Amendment Act, 1966 which introduces Art. 233A in the Constitution.

facts.text: Selection Committee consisted of Chief Justice, Administrative Judge, and another Judge nominated by Chief Justice.

anchor.surface_text: the Selection Committee, appointed under the said Rules and consisting of the Chief Justice, the Administrative Judge and another Judge of the High Court nominated by the Chief Justice,

facts.text: Permanent strength: District and Sessions Judges at 18 (15 judgeships, one Legal Remembrancer, one Registrar of High Court, one Joint Legal Remembrancer); Civil and Additional District Judges at 20.

anchor.surface_text: Schedule I provides the strength of District and Sessions Judges at 18, i.e., 15 judgeships, one post of Legal Remembrance, one post of Registrar of the High Court, and one post of Joint Legal Remembrancer and that of the Civil and Additional District Judges at 20.

facts.text: Governor fixed number of appointments as 18: 14 by promotion, 4 by direct recruitment, for period up to end of 1962, per letter dated December 8, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from the Governments letter dated December 8, 1962, that under Rule 10 the Governor fixed the number of appointments to be made as 18, 14 out of which were to be filled up by promotion and 4 by direct recruitment and the proposed recruitment for these vacancies was to be upto the period ending 1962.

facts.text: On November 9, 1960, 9 Judicial Officers were confirmed in 9 out of the 18 posts.

anchor.surface_text: it appears that on November 9, 1960, 9 Judicial Officers were confirmed in 9 out of the 18 posts with the result that only 9 posts remained to be filled up.

facts.text: Civil and Additional Sessions Judge appointments are to District Judge posts per Article 236 definition.

anchor.surface_text: Article 236 (a) defines a District Judge as including... Sessions Judge, Additional Sessions Judge and Assistant Sessions Judge.

facts.text: Rajasthan Government notification dated June 2, 1950 appointed Civil Judges as Additional Sessions Judges.

anchor.surface_text: By a notification dated June 2, 1950 the Rajasthan Government appointed with effect from July 1, 1950, Civil Judges therein mentioned by virtue of their office to be Additional Sessions Judges...

facts.text: Appellants contended that appointments infringed Rules 10 and 24 by including unfilled vacancies.

anchor.surface_text: the contention was that under Rule 10, the period of recruitment is prospective... while determining the number of posts for which recruitment was to be made the Governor could not take into account vacancies remaining unfilled at the time.

facts.text: Supreme Court rejected appellants' contention on Governor's determination of appointments under Rule 10.

anchor.surface_text: There is, in our view, therefore, no validity in the contention that the determination of the number of appointments by the Governor was contrary to Rule 10...

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: These were the only contentions raised on behalf of the appellants. In our view, they cannot be sustained. The appeal is, therefore, dismissed.

facts.text: Rajasthan Higher Judicial Service Rules apply to District and Sessions Judges and Civil and Additional Sessions Judges.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 1 (2) of the Rajasthan Higher Judicial Service Rules provides that the said Rules shall apply to the members of the Service consisting of District and Sessions Judges and Civil and Additional Sessions Judges.

facts.text: Direct recruitment limited to one-fourth of total strength and vacancies per Rule 10.

anchor.surface_text: Provided that the number of persons appointed to the Service by direct recruitment shall at no time exceed one-fourth of the total strength of the Service and the number of persons so appointed during any one period of recruitment shall not exceed one-fourth of the total number of vacancies occurring during that period.

facts.text: Appointments made by Governor from lists in order: first three from promotion list, fourth from direct recruitment list per Rule 24.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 24 provides that all appointments to posts in the Service shall be made by the Governor... The first three vacancies shall be filled from the list prepared under Rule 13 and the fourth vacancy shall be filled from the list prepared under Rule 22 and so on.

facts.text: High Court only transmits lists prepared by Selection Committee, no power to modify.

anchor.surface_text: There is no provision in Rule 13 or in any other Rule empowering the High Court to modify the lists prepared by the Committee either by substituting others...

facts.text: Rules similar to U.P. Higher Judicial Service Rules invalidated in Chandra Mohan v. State of Uttar Pradesh.

anchor.surface_text: Recently, the U.P. Higher Judicial Service Rules for recruitment of District Judges, which were similar, if not almost identical, with the Rules in this appeal, came up for consideration by this Court in Chandra Mohan V. State of Uttar Pradesh.

holdings.text: The Rules, therefore, are clearly inconsistent with the mandate provided for in Art. 233 and are, therefore, invalid. Consequently, the selections made by the Committee, the lists prepared by them and appointments made thereunder would be invalid.

anchor.surface_text: The Rules, therefore, are clearly inconsistent with the mandate provided for in Art. 233 and are, therefore, invalid. Consequently, the selections made by the Committee, the lists prepared by them and appointments made thereunder would be invalid.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rules substitute consultation with Selection Committee for consultation with the entire High Court required by Art. 233; High Court reduced to transmitting authority without power to modify lists; follows Chandra Mohan precedent on similar U.P. rules.

holdings.text: Appointment to the post of a Civil and Additional Sessions Judge is an appointment of a District Judge within Art. 236(a) as it is substantive appointment as Additional Sessions Judge under CrPC s.9(3), not mere investment of powers.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Solicitor-General, on the other hand, argued that the appointment of a person as a Civil and Additional Sessions Judge would not mean that he is only a Civil Judge or that he is not an Additional Sessions Judge included in the definition of a District Judge by Art. 236.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art. 236(a) explicitly includes Additional Sessions Judge in District Judge definition; appointment under CrPC s.9(3) distinct from investment of powers under ss.36-39; 1950 notification confirms; distinguishes Civil Judge post.

holdings.text: Appointments made in contravention of Art. 233 validated by Art. 233A of the Constitution introduced by Constitution (Twentieth Amendment) Act, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: Since the appointments in question were made in contravention of Art. 233 and were, therefore, illegal they must be held to have been validated under the new Art. 233A.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appointments to District Judge posts (including Civil and Additional Sessions Judges) prior to commencement deemed valid notwithstanding non-compliance with Art. 233 or 235.

holdings.text: No infringement of Rules 10 and 24; Governor entitled to include prior unfilled vacancies in determining recruitment numbers; contention rejected.

anchor.surface_text: There is, in our view, therefore, no validity in the contention that the determination of the number of appointments by the Governor was contrary to Rule 10...

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 10 permits prospective determination including unfilled vacancies; no bar in rules; academic as only 9 posts left after confirmations; Governor's determination valid.

anchor.surface_text: These were the only contentions raised on behalf of the appellants. In our view, they cannot be sustained. The appeal is, therefore, dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: All contentions rejected; rules invalid but appointments validated; no rule infringements.

holdings.text: Question of claim of seniority of Respondents 6 and 7 left open as it does not strictly arise.

anchor.surface_text: We leave the question of the claim of seniority of Respondents 6 and 7, if any, open as it does not strictly arise in this appeal.

holdings.text: Constitutional validity of Art. 233A not decided as not raised.

anchor.surface_text: We may at this stage make it clear that the question of constitutional validity of Art. 233A has not been raised in this appeal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Not challenged; interveners disallowed from arguing.
